user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of send_bad_request:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
send_bad_request (struct MHD_Connection *con)
{
  struct MHD_Response *res;
  enum MHD_Result ret;

  res =
    MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (strlen (BAD_REQUEST_PAGE),
                                            (const void *) BAD_REQUEST_PAGE);
  ret = MHD_queue_response (con, MHD_HTTP_BAD_REQUEST, res);
  MHD_destroy_response (res);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The function is the only code fragment that could be suspect for Rule 2.1 because it has internal linkage (static). If this static function is never referenced elsewhere in the project, the entire function would be unreachable (dead) and should be investigated. No other parts of the provided code fragment contain unreachable statements: there are no conditional branches, labels, gotos, switch cases, or code after a return that would create unreachable statements within the function body. The sequence of calls and the final return are all reachable when the function is invoked, so they do not need further investigation for unreachable code. (Whether the function is actually unreachable in the whole project depends on the wider build—this listing flags the function definition so that callers/usages can be checked.)
